title: Thornhedge
author: Kingfisher, T.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Thornhedge is a highly original take on the story of Sleeping Beauty, where the “evil” fairy responsible for the curse is actually the hero of the stoThornhedge is a highly original take on the story of Sleeping Beauty, where the “evil” fairy responsible for the curse is actually the hero of the story. Toadling, our perspective character, is that fairy. She’s guarded the tower beyond the thorns for years, decades, centuries. And she made my heart ache. Toadling is such a sweet, lovable, quietly heroic character who has no inkling of her own attributes. She is also a tragic character; thus the heart ache. When a knight refuses to be turned back from his quest for the tower by anything Toadling does, she panics. But she also ends up making a friend, quelling her loneliness for the first time in years beyond her measure.The fairy portrayal was a unique and interesting one. Toadling is (kind of) one of the low Fae, more akin to an animal spirit or a brownie than to one of the more beautiful, mysterious Fae so popular in modern fantasy. There is more to her than first appears, but what exactly that “more” is comes into play later in the book. I loved Toadling’s description of her Fae family, and why she found these creatures that would be described as ugly by the world’s standards to be so beautiful in her eyes.I was enthralled by the opening of the story. The way in which the progression of time was presented in the first chapter was absolutely fascinating. We are seeing the slow move of time through Toadling’s eyes. We can piece together what exactly is happening in history, but she has no context for it. I was also, yet again, impressed with range of Kingfisher’s writing, especially when it comes to tone. I’ve read a few of her books now, and each has been radically different in tone and voice. This particular story feels very much like a classic fairytale in setting, but the maudlin tone lends it this achingly lovely air, akin to some gothic novels. It made my heart hurt to read it, but in the best way.I was thoroughly impressed with Thornhedge. Novellas tend to be very hit-or-miss for me, but this one worked in every way. From setting to writing to characters to the actual story being told, I just loved everything about it. I also think this would make a wonderful Studio Ghibli movie, as I could just picture this story drawn in Miyazaki’s style. This was a beautiful little tale that I will be thinking about for a while, and it’s probably my favorite take on Sleeping Beauty I’ve ever read....more

title: The Chosen: I Have Called You By Name        (The Chosen, #1)
author: Jenkins, Jerry B.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I absolutely love The Chosen. I think it’s a wonderfully, prayerfully crafted show. From casting to acting, from script writing to set and costume desI absolutely love The Chosen. I think it’s a wonderfully, prayerfully crafted show. From casting to acting, from script writing to set and costume design, you can tell how much care has been put into every element of the series, and how careful the show runners have been to stay true to the Bible. Unfortunately, like most incredibly popular pieces of art, it’s incredibly divisive. I find it heartbreaking how many Christians find the show blasphemous. Is the show word for word exactly the same as Scripture? Of course not. Characters have been written in and backstories have been expanded. The writers of the Gospels were more concerned with conveying the teachings of Jesus and the events of His life, death, and resurrection, than with telling a compelling story. And yet, the writers of the show are incredibly careful to never deviate from the Gospel. They are merely trying to showcase the unlikely cast of characters Jesus called to follow Him, the eponymous chosen, and give us an idea of who they might have been. The Chosen is not presenting itself as the fifth Gospel. It seeks to tell a good story, a story that has been expanded in terms of character development so that we can remember that the disciples were people like us. Such stories used to be more common, with Ben-Hur and The Robe serving as examples. We as a modern society have lost the distinction between truth and fact. A story can be true without being comprised of only fact. After all, Jesus most often taught in stories, though we fancy them up by calling them parables.And now, onto this actual book.The Chosen: I Have Called You By Name is a direct novelization of season 1 of the show. And I do mean direct. This is nearly word-for-word, scene for scene, the entire story of that season. As a lover of the show, this didn’t bother me. I might have hoped for a little bit of new or different or a slightly deeper dive into the internal monologues of the characters, but I was still happy with the story being told. I found it well written, though most of the chapters were almost obnoxiously short, and I say that as a reader who prefers short chapters. Some of these chapters were only a page long. I felt like they likely lined up exactly with the length of the scenes from the show. But overall, this was a fun way to revisit the show, and is among the better biblical fiction I’ve read....more

This is her most recent purchase, and she pushed it into my hands as soon as she fiActual rating: 3.5 starsMy mom has a thing for coffee table books. This is her most recent purchase, and she pushed it into my hands as soon as she finished it. I understand why, because it provides a fascinating overview of Christian churches across the globe through pictures. While I did find it interesting, and lovely to flip through, I had a few issues with it. Some of the descriptions mentioned the inside of a church while only providing a picture of the exterior, or vice versa. I wish that hadn’t been the case. If you’re going to detail this important piece of interior architecture, please let me see it! Also, some of the pictures themselves could have been better. I’ve personally seen better pictures of a handful of these churches elsewhere. If you’re publishing an art book of any kind, I think you should ensure that you’re presenting the loveliest photos possible. All of that being said, I still found this an interesting read. It was a tour around the world unlike any other I’ve experienced. ...more

title: Greenwild        (Greenwild, #1)
author: Thomson, Pari
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Actual rating: 4.5 stars.Is there anything more delightful than finding a magical new story that can be loved by readers of any age? The last such booActual rating: 4.5 stars.Is there anything more delightful than finding a magical new story that can be loved by readers of any age? The last such book I found was Nevermoor: The Trials of Morrigan Crow, and the series that follows it. While created for middle grade readers, the writing and the story being told are well-crafted enough to appeal to any adult reader. I would put Greenwild in the same category. As an added bonus, the book itself is gorgeous, chock-full of illustrations, large and small. There’s even a full-colored map serving as the endpapers!Daisy Thistledown has lived life on the road. Her mom, Leila, is a famous investigative journalist specializing in environmental politics. The globetrotting nature of Daisy’s childhood has been charming but lonely, and she regrets that she’s never been able to put down roots. But when Leila goes missing and Daisy is being chased through London, she finds her way into a world within our world: Greenwild, the home of a botanical magic that Daisy never knew existed. While Daisy is terribly worried about her mother, she also finds her place in the world for the first time. In Greenwild, she finds not only magical plants, but friends and a sense of belonging and, for the first time in her life, a home.Greenwild was billed as The Secret Garden meets A Wrinkle in Time. I absolutely agree with that first comparison. The second is a bit more of a stretch; the only real commonality is the fact that the Greenwild, the magical world of this book, exists in pocket dimensions within our own world. The pockets are entered through various botanical gardens, which I thought was a really fun decision. I’ve also seen some Harry Potter comparisons that I think are fair. The magical school here feels very much life a Hogwarts that is completely focussed on Herbology. There’s a Snape character, a bit of a Draco and a somewhat Hermione. There were things about the story that felt very reminiscent of Harry Potter. However, I didn’t find it derivative. I thought it was unique enough to feel in part inspired by these stories while still being very much its own thing.There is going to be at least one more book in this series, and I can’t wait to see what happens never with Daisy and her friends. I really enjoyed my time with this story, and it’s one that I think my niece is going to love in a few years. I would recommend this to readers of any age who are looking for something fantastical and whimsical with plenty of plot. And if you happen to be a plant person, I think you’re really going to love Greenwild....more

title: A Tale of Two Cities
author: Dickens, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’m trying to slowly make my way through all of Dickens’ work, and this is one of the biggest omissions still on the list. While I read abridged versiI’m trying to slowly make my way through all of Dickens’ work, and this is one of the biggest omissions still on the list. While I read abridged versions as a child, I had never read A Tale of Two Cities in its entirety. I’m very glad that is no longer the case. I have to admit that this was a more difficult reading experience than most of the other books I’ve read from Dickens. Oliver Twist and Great Expectations and David Copperfield are all pretty straight forward. Bleak House is a bit denser and more convoluted, but I had a wonderful professor guide me through that one in college, thus giving me an advantage when it came to fully digesting the story being told. And then there’s A Christmas Carol, which I had experienced in so many different forms as a child that I had no problem following the story when I finally came to the original. But then I got to A Tale of Two Cities, which is quite possibly the most well known work ever penned. It’s also one of the most unusual in terms of writing and structure.In most of Dickens’ books, we follow a very specific main character. From Oliver Twist to Pip to David Copperfield to Ebenezer Scrooge, it’s always very clear whose story is being told, and who we’ll be following throughout the narrative. Not so with A Tale of Two Cities. The cast is expansive. While said cast is interesting and varied, I didn't know who was meant to be the focus. Was it Doctor Manette? Lucie? Charles Darney? Someone else entirely? The plot seems to be going in so many directions, none of them clear. It’s a story that feels unfocussed and unimportant and honestly unnecessary for a while. After the brilliant opening lines, of course, which are among the most famous in all literature. But for hundreds of pages after that, I found myself wondering what was the point. Through the first two thirds of the book, I was just trudging through, so I could check this off my list. It wasn’t horrible or anything, but I wasn’t seeing what made this story special in any way.Until I did see. When I reached the last third of the book, I was suddenly blown away by how everything came together. Every character, every seemingly divergent strand of plot, every detail that I thought was unimportant, suddenly mattered and braided together to make a cohesive, beautiful, heartbreaking, incredibly powerful whole. I was blown away by the plotting and the character development. The cast had been expansive and the storyline muddled because the French Revolution itself was the main character, and was the true story being told. We see the multitude of reasons why the Revolution occurred, and why it was even necessary in a way, but also why it failed. (Side note: we also meet one of Dickens' most disturbing villains, who personifies the Revolution perfectly.) We see a society so deeply in revolt against the vices that oppressed them that they throw out all virtue, as well. And yet we see that virtue fight back in the most unlikely and moving of ways. What seemed like a defeat of goodness at the novel was really a quiet victory for morality. I actually wept, and I can’t remember the last time a classic elicited that kind of emotion from me.In one chapter, there is the most poignant, heartbreaking, and yet subtle declarations of love I’ve ever read. In the final chapters, we see that love realized in breathtaking ways. We see selfishness and vice die in the life of someone so that selflessness and kindness can take root in their place. It was the kindness that surprised and moved me the most. I was reminded of Jesus, and that is the highest compliment I can pay a story or a character, because He is the epitome of good, and His is the Greatest Story Ever Told. When I was halfway into A Tale of Two Cities, I was disappointed that it felt so bloated and unfocussed. By the time I had reached the final pages, I was blown away by what a unique, powerful tale Dickens had penned. This still isn’t my favorite Dickens novel, but I have immense respect for it, and it is definitely one I will be revisiting in the future....more

title: Swallows and Amazons        (Swallows and Amazons, #1)
author: Ransome, Arthur
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Swallows and Amazons is the installment in a twelve book series by the same name. These are classic adventure stories for children, in the same vein aSwallows and Amazons is the installment in a twelve book series by the same name. These are classic adventure stories for children, in the same vein as The Boxcar Children. We have a group of siblings embarking on an adventure, with a hint of a mystery in the mix. But, for the most part, we are along for the ride as they go through their day to day lives, enjoying life with a little distance from adults. In both series, there’s a delicious emphasis on the meals the children prepare for themselves. There are a few main differences between The Boxcar Children and Swallows and Amazons. In The Boxcar Children, the siblings are orphans, surviving the best they can on their own until they’re adopted at the end of the first book. In Swallows and Amazons, the siblings (both sets) have very supportive mothers who endorse their adventures. Also, in this series, there are two sets of siblings who become friends, versus the one set of siblings in The Boxcar Children. But the biggest difference had to be in the sailing emphasis in Swallows and Amazons. If seafaring and the minutia of nautical terms isn’t really your thing, it’s easy to get bogged down in those details. As I did.I thought this was a fun story, but I’m not sure I’ll be reading the other eleven books in the series. While I love the concept of these kids having an adventure on an “abandoned” island while still having the aid and support of the adults in their lives, I felt like it was difficult to wade through all of the sailing passages. But if you have a child in your life who is fascinated with boats and sailing and deserted islands, this would be a wonderful story to share with them....more

title: The Road
author: McCarthy, Cormac
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Actual rating: 4.5 stars.I knew going into The Road that I was in for bleak. But while this post-apocalyptic story is indeed bleak and heavy and hard,Actual rating: 4.5 stars.I knew going into The Road that I was in for bleak. But while this post-apocalyptic story is indeed bleak and heavy and hard, it’s also oddly hopeful. It’s a short book, less than 300 pages, and it’s stylistically unusual. It’s a surprisingly quiet story, balancing on a razor wire between gentleness and brutality, with lots of emotion and depth bubbling under the surface without ever coming fully into the light. It’s a story that inspires a lot of inner contemplation on the part of the reader. I think it’s a book that everyone should read at some point in their adult life, when they are the most willing to really spend time with a story and mull over it from a philosophical standpoint. I can absolutely see why The Road won a Pulitzer.We have two nameless main characters, the man and the boy. As this father and son traverse the post-apocalyptic hellscape that was once our world, they are frequently starving and always living in fear. There aren’t many people left, and there are even fewer animals. The only food remaining is what can be found in cans, and not all of that can be trusted. The world is cold, and covered in ash. The man is determined to get his son to the coast. He doesn’t know why, or what he hopes to find there, but he will not rest until they reach it. Thus, the man and the boy live on the road, terrified of meeting others but even more terrified of standing still. This is a story with layers. Our perspective character is the man, and we are seeing the world through his eyes. But we are sensing it through the eyes of the boy. The man trusts no one, cares for no one but his son, but is trying to put a braver, kinder face on the world for his child’s sake. The boy is more willing to trust, to be kind, to have faith, because of that. But the man has a hard time rectifying what he wants his son to believe with what the man in actuality believes. It leads to a tension that is at times heartbreaking. On this flip side of this, the man clings desperately to life, mostly out of a desire to not watch his son die, whereas the boy would rather die and see what comes after. Because, whatever it is, it has to be better than this existence, this life of hunger and endless journey. This life of the road. But the man tells the boy that they carry the fire, that they care keeping hope and humanity alive just by forcing one foot in front of the other, day after day, whether they want to or not. And isn’t that what life is sometimes?Stylistically, this is a weird one. There are no chapters. No quotation marks. It’s just one continuous stream of story, with tiny breaks here and there. This mirrors the story being told, as our characters endure this brutal monotony of life on the road, broken only be sleep or sickness. Even when something shakes them out of their norm, for good or ill, they always return to the road. I have to confess that these stylistic choices were a bit difficult for me to connect with, but I think that was the point.I found The Road very compelling. The balance of bleakness and hope resonated with me. McCarthy did so much in this story by refusing to lay everything out for us. He encourages readers to think, and deeply, about what’s going on and why. He also encourages them to never give up, even when it would be so much easier to stop striving. Carry the fire....more

title: Silence
author: Endō, Shūsaku
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Actual rating: 4.5 stars, rounded up.Silence is a book I wanted to have read without actually having to read it. I had heard that it was brilliant, a Actual rating: 4.5 stars, rounded up.Silence is a book I wanted to have read without actually having to read it. I had heard that it was brilliant, a fictionalized account of real figures from history, but I also knew that I was going to have a difficult time with the material, with the hardship these Christians faced and the apostasy so many chose. I was right; it was a very difficult read. But it was also incredibly worth the effort. Silence is spiritually profound work of literary genius. It's tragic, but also laden with hope in the end.  I’m in awe of both the message and the craft with which that message was conveyed.“Sin, he reflected, is not what it is usually thought to be; it is not to steal and tell lies. Sin is for one man to walk brutally over the life of another and to be quite oblivious of the wounds he has left behind.”This is the story of Father Rodrigues, a Portuguese Jesuit priest who in 1639 hears that his mentor, Father Ferrara, has recanted his faith while on mission in Japan, amidst the Japanese government’s push to eradicate Christianity from their shores completely. Rodrigues and a fellow priest, Father Garrpe, are determined to get to the bottom to the accusations, to either prove Ferrara’s innocence or bring him back to the faith. After a harsh journey, they reach Japan and are surprised to find clusters of Japanese Christians still clinging to the faith in secret. The priests do what they can for the people, but are soon found out by the authorities. We follow Rodrigues through journey, from excited missionary to outlaw on the run, from his time in prison to what comes after. “Christ did not die for the good and beautiful. It is easy enough to die for the good and beautiful; the hard thing is to die for the miserable and corrupt.”Through it all, Rodrigues feels a kinship with Christ on His road to the Passion. Through it all, he questions God, wondering why He is silent in the face of such severe persecution. Why does God allow those who would follow Him to suffer such appalling treatment, to the point that they weaken and apostasize, trampling the fumie image of the Christ in their desperation to stop the pain? And had these people sacrificed their eternal souls in this moment of exhausted, devastated weakness?“But pity was not action. It was not love. Pity, like passion, was no more than a kind of instinct.”I thought the repetition of silence as a theme was brilliantly handled. It was powerful, and made the entire work more meditative than I would have expected. The comparisons Rodrigues drew between himself and the Christ he so loved were also powerful. But it was in the final comparison between the two, and the answer to the silence, that I found the most intense spiritual significance.There will be spoilers from here on out. If you haven’t read this book (or watched the movie) yet, but would like to, this is where you should scroll away.When Rodrigues discovers that Ferrara truly did recant, and why, he still can’t quite accept it. But when he is put in the same situation, he finds that he cannot make any other choice. For Ferrara was indeed broken by torture, but not his own. Japanese Christians were being tortured in Ferrara’s place, even if said Christians had already recanted their faith. The torture would continue until the priest himself recanted. You see, the Japanese government didn’t care about breaking the converts; they knew that in breaking the priests, they had a better chance of eradicating Christianity completely. And if a religion preaches mercy as their core value, what better way to break a priest than have him choose between saving the lives of the people being tortured in his place, or preserving their priestly pride by refusing to trample on an image of Christ? “Trample! Trample! It is to be trampled on by you that I am here.”When Rodrigues faces the same test, he finds that he cannot choose but to trample. In the climactic scene of the entire book, as Rodrigues finally understands what is happening and accepts that he will have to apostasize, he has this moment where he is staring at the fumie and believes that Christ tells him to trample. He comes to understand that Christ would have done the same, that His pride would never have eclipsed His mercy. It is here that Rodrigues understands God was never silent, that He was suffering right alongside Rodrigues and Ferrara and every Japanese Christian. It is here Rodrigues accepts that there is more than one form of martyrdom, and that he is tasked to suffer that which is least glorious, the martyrdom of his character instead of that of his body. In the end, this is a story about recognizing the heroism of the martyrs of Japan, and at the same time offering grace and forgiveness to those Christians who bowed under the strain.“but our Lord was not silent. Even if he had been silent, my life until this day would have spoken of Him.”Silence is incredibly difficult but equally edifying. It was a perfect book to read over Lent. Not only did grace pour from the page, but the craftsmanship was immaculate. The mindfulness over the inclusion of the silence motif and the comparisons between Christ and Rodrigues really enriched the story being told. Even the gradual shift from first person to third and back felt important. This is a work in translation, and I was very impressed by the work of the translator. I will say that I got bogged down in the middle, which is the only thing that kept me from giving this 5 full stars. It’s a brilliant tale, and one I think every Christian or philosophical thinker should experience in some form....more

title: Raybearer        (Raybearer, #1)
author: Ifueko, Jordan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’ve never read anything quite like Raybearer. From the world building to the plot to the characters, it felt wholly unique from any other fantasy stoI’ve never read anything quite like Raybearer. From the world building to the plot to the characters, it felt wholly unique from any other fantasy story I’ve experienced. And it was beautiful. Powerful. Fierce. I can’t believe this was a debut novel. I’m honestly in awe.Tarisai grew up in Swana in a gilded cage, given all of the privileges of royalty while always remaining trapped and alone, apart from her tutors and servants, all of whom feared her. Her Hallow, or magical power with which she was born, is an ability to see memories carried by any object or person she touches. She longed for her mother, known only as The Lady, to truly see her, and to love her. Instead, The Lady has raised Tarisai to be a weapon, to get to close the Crown Prince of Aritsar, infiltrate his Council of Eleven, and kill him when she loves him most. Under this curse, Tarisai finds herself thrust into a world unlike any she could have imagined, trying desperately to guard the family she’s always craved against the most insidious enemy of all: herself.I found Tarisai an absolutely fascinating character. Her struggle against herself, her naturing warring against her nurture, makes her incredibly sympathetic. I love the way she sees the world, and I love the friends she makes. I was especially taken with Sanjeet and Kirah, the member’s the of the Council of Eleven with whom Tar is the closest, as well as Dayo, the Crown Prince and Raybearer to whom the Council is bound. Sanjeet is a giant of a Dhyrmish boy who wants to use his Hallow, which lets him see the weaknesses and injuries in anyone he meets, to heal. Instead, he’s been trained to kill. Kirah is a Blessid girl, whose Hallow allows her to heal with songs. Dayo is so unlike his father, sweet and good and loving. He’s a Raybearer, who is strengthened by his Council to be unkillable by anything but old age — or by the hand of one of his Council. Each Emperor of Aritsar is a Raybearer is gifted this near immortality through their magical bond with their chosen Council. Council members have to love their Raybearer with their whole heart in order to become one with their Emperor’s Ray. Through this Ray, all of the Council siblings can share thoughts and feelings. It’s a bond closer than blood, so much so that, once you are part of a Council, you must tay close to your Council siblings or suffer a debilitating Council sickness. I adore found family tropes, and this is one of the most unique approaches to that I've come across. There must be one Council member from each of the 11 realms of Aritsar. There’s one other realm, Songland, but it is not considered part of the Empire and is cursed. Each member of the Council must have one of the aforementioned Hallows, and I found them simply lovely in their variety. No Hallow is exactly the same as someone else’s. That’s one of the things that made the magic in this book so unique. There’s no set system. It’s wild, and give out as the deity of this world, Am the Storyteller, deems fit. This made for one of the most interesting and unique fantasy worlds I’ve ever visited. One of my favorite things about this story is the emphasis on embracing who you are, and all of the facets that make you that person. In this story, cultural identity is incredibly important. Each of the twelve realms of Aritsar has a strong cultural identity, displayed in the songs they sing and the drums they play and the patterns and cloth they wear. When the Empire decides to push hard for unity, the first thing they do is try to suppress and destroy all of these expressions of identity, burning drums and songs and fabrics and doling out more uniform replacements. There’s a line from later in the book that I found powerful: “Uniformity is not unity. Silence is not peace.” We are the most united when we embrace our differences instead of trying to erase them.I loved everything about this book. The world was unlike any other I’ve read. The characters stole my heart. It’s been a long time since I loved a protagonist so completely as I did Tarisai. The writing was perfect for the story being told, lyrical without the prose ever supplanting the plot. It’s a powerful tale of justice and loyalty and identity, and I can’t wait to see how the story ends in Redemptor, the second book of the duology....more

title: What If It's True?: A Storyteller’s Journey with Jesus
author: Martin, Charles*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Actual rating: 4.5 stars.What If It’s True? is a beautiful examination of the life of Christ and the words He spoke. According to the jacket copy, MarActual rating: 4.5 stars.What If It’s True? is a beautiful examination of the life of Christ and the words He spoke. According to the jacket copy, Martin began wrestling with a handful of questions regarding the Bible years before writing this book:What if every single word of this story is absolutely true and I can trust it?What if the King of the universe is speaking directly to me through the words of His book?And if I believe His Word is true, how should I respond?This book is his attempt to answer those questions. He tackles the fundamentals of the Christian faith with grace and depth, digging deep where it would be so much easier to skim the surface. I found his views thought-provoking, enlightening, and firmly rooted in Scripture.I expected the highlight of this book to be the writing itself, as its author was already so well-known for his fiction when he wrote it. But, while the writing was exceptional, I was blown away by Martin’s inclusion of Scripture. You expect a book like this to be littered with Bible verses and references, but Martin also managed to weave Scripture seamlessly into nearly every paragraph in the book. This wasn’t just a list of references. I could tell as I was reading that Martin has spend a tremendous amount of time in the Word, and that he has let it saturate his life, his mind, his speech. These quotations never felt forced; they were as natural as breathing.Usually when reading spiritual nonfiction I have to keep my guard up just a tad. I’ll appreciate when the author makes a good point, and I’ll find things to learn and grow from within the text, but I’m also wary of theological fallacies, of opinion masquerading as fact, of areas where I just can’t agree with the author’s findings because they ring false. I never once encountered anything like that in this book. My theology perfectly aligned with everything Martin wrote. I found myself internally saying Amen often. I also loved the written prayers he included at the end of each chapter, and how much Scripture was woven in there, as well.There were only a couple of elements that kept me from giving this 5 full stars, and those were incredibly subjective. While I thought Martin’s prose was beautiful, there were a few times when he added in a modern but outdated colloquialism, like “my goose is cooked,” or “I’m tripping over my bottom lip,” or “licking his chops,” that I could tell were meant to make a scene more conversational, but which actually made me cringe just a little. Those took me out of the book. Also, I got so bogged down in the middle of the book that I set it aside for months. Not that what was being said wasn’t fantastic; it was. It was just a bit boggy in those middle chapters for me personally.At the time of writing this book, Martin had penned thirteen novels, but this was his first work of nonfiction. He’s done more since then, and I fully intend to read them all. I also plan to go back and try his fiction, as I loved his way with words. There’s a depth to his writing that I find moving. As his novels are by and large all very highly rated and respected, I’m excited to experience his telling of a tale all his own. But he did a brilliant job breaking down portions of The Greatest Story Ever Told, and I can see myself returning to particular chapters of this book over and over, for the rest of my life....more

title: Bread and Wine: Readings for Lent and Easter
author: Arnold, J. Heinrich
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Bread and Wine is a collection of reflections on Lent and Easter and why both matter. As a Protestant, Lent isn’t something I ever observed or even knBread and Wine is a collection of reflections on Lent and Easter and why both matter. As a Protestant, Lent isn’t something I ever observed or even knew much about until the last few years. The same can be said of Advent. But something I’ve come to respect deeply about Catholicism are the sacred rhythms of their year. Evangelicals tend to see Easter and Christmas as important days, sure, but they’re only a day each. Catholics (and some of the more ritualistic Protestant faiths) see the importance of meditating on these events instead of flying through them, of observing a season of preparing the heart for the celebrations. I love this, and it’s something I’m trying to institute in my own life. One of the biggest ways I’m doing this is through reading such meditative works as the writings showcased in Bread and Wine.In this book, we have a collection of 72 brief essays or excerpts about the life, death, burial, and resurrection of Jesus, as well as a handful of poems. No author has more than one inclusion. While there were authors included that I already loved and was familiar with, like C.S. Lewis, Madeline L’Engle, N.T. Wright, G.K. Chesterton, Philip Yancey, and more, I was also introduced to an incredible amount of new-to-me writers, or those I’ve heard of but whose work I’ve never read. Among these were Amy Carmichael, Frederic Buechner, Søren Kierkegaard, and Dorothy Sayers. As with any collection including so many authors, the pieces varied wildly in terms of quality. None were terrible, but some were certainly better than others. There are about twenty that I loved enough to mark so that I could return to them easily. My favorites of these were written by: Barbara Cawthorne Crafton, Kahlil Gibran, Dorothy Sayers, Peter Kreeft, Brennan Manning, Frederica Mathewes-Green, Philip Yancey, Amy Carmichael, Barbara Brown Taylor, and (a poem by) John Updike. I found some of these profoundly moving, or thought-provoking, or both. Many were penned by people from different faith backgrounds from mine, which helped me stretch myself. Even if I didn’t agree with every single piece theologically, they still made me think and look outside of my own narrow beliefs. Overall, I really enjoyed my time with Bread and Wine, and I feel like it did a lot to help prepare my heart to celebrate the Resurrection. The same company has another book, Watch for the Light, that is similar readings for Advent and Christmas, and I will absolutely be buying myself a copy before December. I can see both of these being books that I revisit in part or whole on a yearly basis....more

title: Random in Death        (In Death, #58)
author: Robb, J.D.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Actual rating: 4.5 starsRandom in Death is another wonderful installment in my favorite cop procedural series. While not every single installment has Actual rating: 4.5 starsRandom in Death is another wonderful installment in my favorite cop procedural series. While not every single installment has been among my favorite stories in terms of plot, I don’t think I’ll ever get tired of catching up with Eve and Roarke. Admittedly, the cases are better in some books than they are in others. I felt that this particular installment featured a really solid case. But even better, there was a wonderful balance between the procedural elements and the relational ones. That’s a balance that Eve has worked hard for over the dozens of novels before this one, and I love seeing it finally coming to fruition here. She’s allowing herself to breathe and enjoy life, even in the midst of whatever murder she is trying to solve. After everything she’s been through, it’s beautiful to see. Also, I loved that Roarke was more present in the story than he had been in the last few books. I love their marriage, and the way they’ve softened each other over the years. Both characters shined brightly in this book, demonstrating their kindness and affection to each other, their inner circle, and even to total strangers. It was my favorite element of the entire story.Then there’s the case itself. Teenage girls are being targeted at random at huge events for teens, starting at a concert given by Avenue A. The randomly selected targets are injected with a deadly cocktail of pure heroin, ketamine, a date rape drug, and syphilis, just to add insult into the mix. The very randomness of the case made it difficult to solve. But you always know going into any book in this series that Eve will catch her killer by the end. Something that always impresses me is Nora’s ability to make you care deeply for a character in only a couple of pages, before killing them off. She did that multiple times in this book, but most compellingly in the life of our first victim, Jenna, a sixteen year old aspiring musician. I felt that the world had been robbed of a great talent, even though she had never truly existed in the first place. That shows incredible talent, in my opinion.I deeply appreciate the fact that Nora churns out these books with such regularity. It was a joy getting to spend time with this cast of characters again. The case was compelling, and I was emotionally invested the entire time. Random in Death was a really solid installment in the longest running series I’ve ever kept up with, and I’m already counting down the days until we get book 59!...more

title: That Time I Got Drunk and Saved a Human        (Mead Mishaps, 3)
author: Lemming, Kimberly*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Actual rating: 3.5 starsObviously, Mead Mishaps is a totally addictive. I binged all three currently published installments in three days. I think ThaActual rating: 3.5 starsObviously, Mead Mishaps is a totally addictive. I binged all three currently published installments in three days. I think That Time I Got Drunk and Saved a Human improves upon its predecessor, That Time I Got Drunk and Yeeted a Love Potion at a Werewolf, without quite measuring up to the book that started it all, That Time I Got Drunk and Saved a Demon. That first book was just a lot of fun and, while the other two installments were also enjoyment, they didn’t quite capture that same magic.I’m not going to mention the female lead of this book by name, as that’s kind of a spoiler for previous books. But she was a lot of fun, with just as much sass and snark as I’ve come to expect from Lemming’s leading ladies. And the demon once again falls first, which is a trope I enjoy. Said demon is also charming, funny, kind of clueless, and sometimes absolutely terrifying. Which is a winning combination in a love interest. The two have some great chemistry. This book wasn’t quite as spicy as its predecessor, and I was actually okay with that. Book two was a little much.The amount of tropes in this series is kind of insane. But in a fun way. In this installment alone we had fated mates, marriage of convenience, he falls first, and many more. What I’m not a fan of is the miscommunication or lack of communication trope, which was the driving force behind a lot of the plot in this particular book. If there hadn’t been so much humor in the story, it would have been a major turn-off. However, seeing as the entire series is hilarious, I let it slide.Mead Mishaps is such a funny, frothy, spicy, cozy fantasy series. There are definitely stakes, and a significant amount of bloodshed, but you also can tell from the tone of the storytelling that everything is going to work out in the end. And sometimes a steamy happily ever after is exactly what you need. That Time I Got Drunk and Saved a Demon was my favorite, but I had a serious amount of fun with the entire series. I can’t wait to see what happens next!...more

author: Lemming, Kimberly*

review: Actual rating: 3.5 starsI couldn’t help myself. As soon as I finished That Time I Got Drunk and Saved a Demon, I immediately started That Time I Got DActual rating: 3.5 starsI couldn’t help myself. As soon as I finished That Time I Got Drunk and Saved a Demon, I immediately started That Time I Got Drunk and Yeeted a Love Potion at a Werewolf. And it was just about as cute as its predecessor. Though way, way spicier. The first book was definitely open door, don’t get me wrong. But this book blew the door completely off. You know that TikTok sound that goes “What happened to hello? How are you? My name is?” That echoed in my head as I read one of the raunchiest scenes I’ve ever read in traditionally published fiction right around a third of the way into a very short book. I’m not complaining. I’m just warning you. Be prepared.I liked Brie and Felix, but didn’t feel like they captured quite the same magic as Cinnamon and Fallon. I thought that Brie’s protestations made less sense, and her capitulation came too easily. Then again, she is a serious spicy romance reader herself, and was living her best life. Hard to fault her for that. My favorite aspect was actually the introduction of a new character: the snarky, horny, sentient sword, Alexis. She was fabulous.This entire story felt just a tad rushed to me, in comparison with the first Mead Mishaps book. But was it still fun? Also-freaking-luting. I thoroughly enjoyed my time with it, and immediately moved on to the most recently published installment, That Time I Got Drunk and Saved a Human. This is shaping up to be the perfect comfort read series....more

title: That Time I Got Drunk and Saved a Demon        (Mead Mishaps, #1)
author: Lemming, Kimberly*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: That Time I Got Drunk and Saved a Demon was very outside my norm. Which I knew title alone. But it also sounded light and absolutely adorable. I’ve diThat Time I Got Drunk and Saved a Demon was very outside my norm. Which I knew title alone. But it also sounded light and absolutely adorable. I’ve discovered a love for stories with a cozy fantasy feel, but that have actual stakes and big adventures. Adventures don’t come much bigger than the one in this book. And yet the adventure wasn’t the true heart of the story; the romance was. I generally prefer my romance to be more on the periphery, but I had no problem making an exception here. Because Cinnamon and Fallon are hilarious together. And hot. Scorching, even.Comedic books can be very hit or miss for me. That Time I Got and Saved a Demon was a direct hit. I laughed out loud in certain parts of this story. The cast grows wider and wilder and weirder as the plot progresses, and every addition added more humor. But Cinnamon and Fallon were definitely the stars of the show. This luscious homebody of a spice farmer who hates adventure and the demon she saves get up to some serious shenanigans. The fact that their chemistry is through the roof doesn’t hurt. (This got pretty darn spicy, so consider yourself warned if detailed sex scenes are not your thing.) The banter between the two was immensely entertaining. In fact, all of the dialogue in the story was pretty fantastic.Did I roll my eyes on multiple occasions? Yes. There were parts of the story that felt too convenient, or too over the top, even for a book this fantastical and frothy. I could also tell that the author is a TikTok user, as multiple popular soundbites wormed their way into the story. I wasn’t mad about it. At all. It added to my entertainment. But it also threw me out of the story from time to time, as I could actually hear the references in my head. It was kind of distracting. Fun, but distracting.By and large, this is just a really fun, fast-paced, addictive story. It’s charming and frothy and just plain delightful. I finished this book and immediately began the second in the series, That Time I Got Drunk and Yeeted a Love Potion at a Werewolf. Which, as an aside, has to be one of the wildest titles I’ve ever witnessed. I can see why Mead Mishaps is so popular. That Time I Got Drunk and Saved a Demon is a smile on a page. If the rest of the series is just as light and fun, I can see these being added to the list of books I go back to when I need comfort....more

title: The Ballad of Perilous Graves
author: Jennings, Alex
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Actual rating: 3.5 starsI’ve always had such a deep love and affection for my home state. Louisiana just seems so unique to me. I love our cultural idActual rating: 3.5 starsI’ve always had such a deep love and affection for my home state. Louisiana just seems so unique to me. I love our cultural identity, and nothing encapsulates what makes us so special quite as much as New Orleans. But when Hurricane Katrina hit in 2005 and the levees broke, Nola suffered some truly catastrophic damage. While the city has been mostly rebuilt, the scar remains. The Ballad of Perilous Graves is a fantastical take on the city and the storm, with music at its heart.I was intrigued by The Ballad of Perilous Graves as soon as I heard of it, but it sat unread on my shelf for a long time. Just as books about books tend to be very hit or miss for me, since its a topic so close to my heart, books about Louisiana often leave me vaguely disappointed. There’s something about Louisiana that is magical and instantly recognizable, but for some reason that often proves difficult to capture on the page. Not so here. Jennings beautifully captured Nola in all of its wild, dirty, symphonic glory. Maybe it takes the presence of actual magic to get the feel of New Orleans across. And always, always, there should be music.The magical music in this story had to be my favorite element. Songs were personified and interacting with the city. Death is also a huge part of New Orleans culture, from the cemetery tours to voodoo to just the sheer history of the place. That aspect was phenomenally represented here, with the dead mingling with the living in the forms of haints and zombies and more. There was even a dead side of town that felt completely right. But it was the music running through the veins of the city and the story that really captured me.There were some wonderful characters here, but Perry, our eponymous character, was definitely my favorite. His journey, joined by his little sister Brendy and their friend Peaches, was fascinating to follow. But Casey, our other main perspective character, was where the story lost me. It wasn’t Casey himself that was the problem, exactly. I just found his portion of the story far more difficult to follow. Which leads me to what didn’t work for me about this book.The setting was exquisitely rendered, but the story itself was a mess. It felt jumbled and incredibly difficult to follow. Sometimes I wouldn’t figure out what was going on in a particular scene until chapters later. I felt like I was barely treading water when it came to the actual plot, which just doesn’t make for an enjoyable reading experience. I was reminded of a painting that is wonderful from a distance, with your eyes slightly unfocussed, but when you come closer and really look at individual elements, it falls apart.I would give this book 5 stars for vibes and setting, and 2 stars for the actual progression of the story. So I’m cutting it right in the middle with a 3.5 star rating. Even though the plot left me feeling dissatisfied, The Ballad of Perilous Graves is worth reading for its depiction of New Orleans alone. Nola is so lovingly, powerfully, honestly rendered here. It’s one of the best fictional representations of what makes Louisiana special that I’ve ever read....more

title: Defiant        (Skyward, #4)
author: Sanderson, Brandon*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Actual rating: 4.5 starsDefiant is an emotional, action-packed finale to what has become one of my favorite young adult series, as well as one of my fActual rating: 4.5 starsDefiant is an emotional, action-packed finale to what has become one of my favorite young adult series, as well as one of my favorite sci-fi series. While I thought that it took a bit longer for the plot to take off than with most of the other installments in the Skyward series, it more than made up for it with the expected Sanderlanche at the end. This book was tense, heartbreaking, hopeful, and incredibly engaging. What a solid end to a solid story.Because this is the finale in a series, I won’t be discussing any specifics. Instead, I want to talk about some of the elements I loved most. A huge part of the entire series is the addressing of the question of what makes a person. It’s about acknowledging someone’s worth, even when they couldn’t be more different than you. To demonstrate this, Sanderson crafted some incredibly unique alien races. I was charmed by the kitsen, tiny foxlike beings with a samurai-inspired culture. I fell in love with the taynix, the compassionate slugs that house such power. There are races made of crystals, giant lizard people who are bonded to trees, small crablike creatures in giant suits, and so many more. There are the mysterious, terrifying delvers. And, of course, there are the humans. The defiant, fallible, brilliantly brave humans. The way so many of these peoples come together is beautiful.Which brings me to my favorite aspect of the entire series: the friendships. Across boundaries of class structure or of species, across the galaxy, found families are formed. Whether it’s between Skyward flight, or between a girl and her ship, or her tiny fox ninja, or her parrot of a slug, these friendships are what made this story so special to me. These connections gave me so many feelings. I also love how much emphasis is put on finding out who you are, and fighting for your right to be that person. It’s also about finding where you belong, and the people you belong with. There’s significant character development over the course of the series, but it always feels honest. While the battles and subterfuge and warfare are all engaging, those elements aren’t what this series is about; it’s about humanity, it all its many forms.That being said, Sanderson did a brilliant job with the action sequences. I’ve always had a difficult time following battles. Take those battles off of the ground, and I’m even more lost. But I was never lost here. I was always able to follow every maneuver. And I appreciate how much emotion Sanderson is always able to attach to these action scenes. I was moved to tears multiple times in the climactic scenes of this book.I thoroughly enjoyed the Skyward series, and Defiant was a wonderful way to wrap things up. While it got a bit of a slow start, it made for any incredibly strong finish. I’m excited to see where Sanderson takes readers in his follow-up series, Skyward Legacy....more

title: Fifty Beasts to Break Your Heart: And Other Stories
author: Nethercott, GennaRose*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was my first experience with Nethercott’s writing, and it immediately resonated with me. But approaching this , I found myself drawing a blThis was my first experience with Nethercott’s writing, and it immediately resonated with me. But approaching this , I found myself drawing a blank. It was a really solid collection, with far more hits than misses, and I felt that there was a wonderful cohesion to the collection as a whole. I loved the dark fairy tale vibes. But that’s pretty much all I can come up with. Short story collections are difficult to rate and . I feel that each story deserves its own attention. So, instead of giving an overarching , I’m going to include the notes I kept as I read each story. They’re rough, and some are basically just quotes, but they’re what stood out to me as I was reading. If you want to know if I think the collection is worth your time, the answer is yes. If you want to know what I thought of each story, you can find that below, along with my rating of each.Sundown at the Eternal Staircase: 3[ ] Right off the bat, Nethercott has a fascinating writing style. I was reminded of Neil Gaiman and Kelly Link, but Nethercott's voice is also completely unique.[ ] I like the cyclical nature of the story; it was fitting for a tale focussed around a supernatural stairway.[ ] However, while I was interested in the structure and the staircase itself, the story didn't do much for me. It felt half-formed.A Diviner's Abecedarian: 5[ ] The alphabet setup of this is wonderful. A story in tiny vignettes.[ ] Serious Coven vibes, but younger.[ ] I like how none of the six girls in the group is ever named. Instead, they are "the one of us with the long blonde hair" or "the one of us with the hoop earrings."[ ] This kind of groupthink, as well as the shared belief of your own imaginings and how special you are collectively, and the mean girl behavior, feel wholly accurate regarding girls of that age.[ ] But how much of their "magic" is imagined, and how much is in some way real?[ ] We are also give a subtle glance into what it's like to be the New Girl, the outsider in a group like this.[ ] Loved this one. Incredibly unique!The Thread Boy: 5[ ] This one felt very much like a fairytale in tone and style.[ ] The constant sewing imagery was a lovely touch.[ ] A lovely, somewhat maudlin look at how we can't help but leave a piece of ourselves behind with every relationship, experience, and place that matters. Those ties can hurt, but they're also what make life so beautiful.Fox Jaw: 1.5[ ] "It's true--you can't really be angry with someone without loving them first. Sort of the way that you can't cook a meal without heating the pan. You have to care to the point that the grease starts spitting up at you in pinpricks, and then, only then, can the anger start."[ ] You can't give other people pieces of yourself. You need all of them. And yet, we can't help but give ourselves away, anyway. Those who take the most deserve the least.[ ] This story is really strange. And not necessarily in a good way. It's unusual and poetic, and oddly repellent. The War of Fog: 3.5[ ] "The more I grow to love a man, the less I tend to like him."[ ] "War cannot be imagined, for those who have not witnessed it cannot truly fathom it, and for those who have borne witness--it is no longer an imagining. It is a boot print permanently crushed into the heart."[ ] "No war could be more sanguinary. More storied. Yes, this is THE War. The only war that has ever been or will be--because it is ours. In this way, war is like love."[ ] This story felt very metaphysical, describing a war in a time loop, but only from a peripheral viewpoint. A fascinating concept that I wish I'd been quicker to grasp. Drowning Lessons: 3[ ] "My sister has drowned 37 times." What an opener.[ ] "Maybe this is the difference between want and yearn: Want can be flipped on and off like a fuse. Want can be indulged in or set aside. Yearn is something else. You can hear it in the shape of the word."[ ] "If nobody really knows you, then no one knows if you’re telling the truth. And if no one knows if you’re telling the truth, you can decide what the truth is, and what it isn’t. You have the control. Even when the water is rising."[ ] Odd. Sad. Lonely.The Autumn Kill: 4[ ] The tone here makes me think of Greek myth, as if the narrator is a huntress of Artemis. And then it swaps to a setting rooted in modern reality, with a dystopian vibe.[ ] "I was killed once, too—swept from my mother’s bed and carved into a huntress. My neighbors sharpened my hands into bayonets. Turned my hip to dagger sheath. My teeth, they filed down to points. They made me chant the song a spine sings when it breaks. Little lullaby. Then they married me to the Hunter’s Moon, and I wore a dog-jaw crown."[ ] "Please shut up about the end of the world. Yes, the world changed. It does not matter how or when. All worlds end, at some point, and new ones sprout from them."[ ] "We use the debris of our old lives as weapons. Everything can be a weapon, if held skillfully."[ ] Dark. Sad. Fierce. Resigned. Defiant.Fifty Beasts to Break Your Heart: 3[ ] A bestiary, but an exceedingly odd one. Written by florists, for when flowers aren't meaningful enough, or can't convey what needs to be understood.[ ] "Monsters and flowers aren't much different."[ ] "But what to do when the primrose is not enough? When the greenhouse can no longrt contain a client's longing? Then--a bolder bouquet is needed."[ ] Some of the wording gave me Gaiman vibes. Some creatures reminded me of Studio Ghibli films, like Spirited Away.[ ] There is a bit of a through-plot binding this piece together, but it's a weird one.[ ] Some of the illustrations feel like fever dreams.A Lily is a Lily: 4[ ] "As everyone knows, when a person is missed enough, a ghost is born."[ ] "Like any gaseous form, she could expand and contract to fill the container of his heart in whatever way it needed to be filled."[ ] "Every detail of her too sharp, too true, too present. She left nothing to long for, to reach toward, and miss."[ ] Can you love the memory of someone so much that the reality of them is a disappointment?[ ] Sweet, maudlin, sad.Dear Henrietta: 3.5[ ] "Have you ever kept a secret for no good reason? Maybe it wasn’t juicy enough to tell. Maybe there was no one you liked well enough to tell it to. Or maybe you kept the secret so well, you even kept it from yourself—and when you reached to retrieve it, the secret hovered on the edge of your memory like an insect, batting and batting against a screen door, but fluttering off when you tried to catch it in the cage of your fingers."[ ] This felt like an a24 movie. Very odd and inexplicably creepy. Unsettling. Possessions: 3.5[ ] "I heard once that everybody dies twice—once when their heart stops, and again when their name is spoken for the last time. But there is another sort of dying in between, a crueler death: when those you love begin to make choices they would never make if you were there. If you were alive. Things that would be thoughtless, brutal even, but in your absence, become benign."[ ] Another sad, existentially disturbing little story.Homebody: 4[ ] 2nd person. Always a risk. Tends to work better for short stories than longer form fiction, though.[ ] "The first moment you saw Marlow, you didn’t love him. Then in the second moment, you did." - A lovely way to convey falling in love. But sometimes, those first instincts are correct.[ ] This relationship felt dangerous to me from the first night, bound to gradually become more and more toxic and controlling.[ ] The subtle shift from feeling pretty to feeling less, all because of one remark. A textbook opening line of abuse.[ ] This story is all about how much of yourself you will give away or tamp down in order to please a person, and how that level of capitulation is rarely enough to keep them. Incredibly sad.A Haunted Calendar: 2.5[ ] "Day 6 Ghost (noun): The suspended sensation of watching a wineglass tilt off a table’s edge—knowing it will shatter, but being powerless to stop it."[ ] "Day 25 Fact: Ghosts do not belong only to the dead. They belong to whatever is absent. A sweetheart. A misplaced key. A hometown you fled in a glinting jet plane while swearing never, never to return."[ ] Some of these entries feel like those 2 sentence horror stories. Other feel like observations or poetic musings on death or hauntings.[ ] The way it ends is unsettling.The Plums at the End of the World: 5[ ] The dangers of repressed desire, and how it will inevitably lead you to crazier actions than what you craved in the first place.[ ] "...yearning can shackle you if you don't treat it kindly."[ ] "No, my monstrosity is not animal, nor human. It comes from a blending of the two."[ ] “It’s not the dark we’re afraid of,” the goat girl continued, “it’s being in darkness with eyes that were built for the light. It’s not a lone ghost we’re afraid of—it’s the ghost appearing in the realm of the living, in the same room as our breathing bodies. We are never afraid of a thing on its own, as it is. We’re afraid of something intruding in a context in which it doesn’t belong."[ ] "What is a monster? It’s a contradiction. A creature who houses two dissonant aspects... Am I a monster? Yes, love, I am. I am a monster because I contain too much.”[ ] “What is a monster but someone who can see this world from both sides? ... What is monster if not someone, some thing, caught between?”[ ] A brilliant, horrid way to end the collection....more

title: The Word is Murder        (Hawthorne & Horowitz, #1)
author: Horowitz, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There’s nothing quite like a good mystery. The tension, the pacing, the doling out of revelations. The large and varied cast of characters, none of whThere’s nothing quite like a good mystery. The tension, the pacing, the doling out of revelations. The large and varied cast of characters, none of whom you can ever trust completely. The way everything comes together in the end and how, when done really well, you can see where the author had given you so many clues, most of which go unnoticed until viewed in hindsight. But for every good mystery, there are dozens of subpar ones. When you find a mystery author you can trust to deliver, you still with them. Antony Horowitz is one of those I full intend to stick with.I couple of years ago I read my first Horowitz novel, Magpie Murders. Not only did I love it while I was reading it, I continued thinking about it months after I read the final pages. I thought it was exceptionally well done. And the limited series does by Masterpiece Mystery was possibly even better. As Horowitz adapted the story for screen himself, this was completely unsurprising to me. After having loved both the book and screen adaptation of Magpie Murders so much, I was already pretty certain that I could trust Horowitz as a writer. Having now read The Word is Murder, all doubt as been removed. At first, I thought the entire concept behind this book was kind of weird. I love the idea of a writer teaming up with a detective to solve a crime, don’t get me wrong. One of my favorite comfort tv series is Castle. But the author in Horowitz’s story being Horowitz himself? I wasn’t sure how well that was going to work. I love when authors break the fourth wall successfully, but it’s hard to pull off well. As soon as Horowitz began inserting discourse about his other works, I had to fight off my skepticism. However, he ended up growing on me as a character. It was interesting seeing how he would balance his own voice within the story. There were times when I wasn’t sure how reliable a narrator he was, which was a fun writing choice. I found the entire novel lightly campy, in the very best way possible.And then there’s Hawthorne himself. Our detective is almost wholly unlikeable. He might be brilliant, but he plays things so close to the vest that it’s difficult to determine. I found him unpleasant much of the time, and downright awful periodically. He’s incredibly abrasive, and I found him difficult to understand. Much the same difficulties Horowitz himself had. But he grew on me as he grew on Horowitz. The case we follow was never boring, and actually ended up going in a completely different direction than the one I predicted. This misdirection was made even more entertaining by the fact that Horowitz was just as befuddled. I really appreciated how he recapped the clues he himself had written without even registering them as clues. That was an interesting touch that felt somewhat unique.As for the writing, I fell in love with Horowitz’s style on the first page. Again. He has such an easy, classy, charming way with words. And he’s clever. I found myself feeling everything he was feeling as a character, which says a lot for his craft. I also really appreciated the stylistic difference between chapter 1 and the rest of the book, as the we are unaware of Horowitz’s personal presence in the case in that first chapter, but have been introduced to him as a character immediately after.The dynamic between Horowitz and Hawthorne was an unusual one, and it kept my attention from start to finish. I was invested in the case, as well as in Horowitz’s conveyance of it. The Word is Murder is just a really solid mystery all around. It’s fun and clever and perfectly paced. I will definitely be reading more in this series!...more

title: The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store
author: McBride, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Actual rating: 3.5 starsThe Heaven & Earth Grocery Store was a difficult book. There is a huge cast of characters, with no single protagonist or antagActual rating: 3.5 starsThe Heaven & Earth Grocery Store was a difficult book. There is a huge cast of characters, with no single protagonist or antagonist. Multiple people fit into both of those camps. The plot is almost ephemeral, proving very difficult to grasp and follow in some places. We get a lot of back stories for seemingly minor characters. And yet, everything somehow comes together in the end. The very lackadaisical telling of it feels like an important aspect of the story. It’s book well worth reading, but it’s by no means easy.I got lost in the minutia of this story, and not in a good way. There were so many briefly mentioned secondary characters, and so much detail, that I felt like I was barely keeping my head above water in certain portions. The plot was incredibly meandering, to the point where it disappeared for chapters at a time. However, there is a section in the book where a particular character is sharing a story with others in the cast as she eats a piece of pie. By the time she’s finished, she has somehow given the group a plan to break a boy out of a horrible facility, and has even provided a map through her dissected pie, all without saying a direct word about it. I feel like that scene, which was in the back half of the book, did a lot to help me understand McBride’s storytelling method for this particular work. He spins a story without ever directly telling you anything. You hear people’s stories, and you watch as events unfold. It’s up to you to piece everything together from the breadcrumbs McBride drops.I had never thought about the intersection of Jews and Blacks during this period of American history, and I found it fascinating. In the 1930s, when the story is set, both groups were still very much looked down upon by whites, and both tended to live grouped close to each other. I loved seeing the intersection of these two groups, and how they banded together in this small town when such unity was needed.Among both groups were a wonderfully varied and engaging cast of characters. My very favorite was Chona. Chona is a wonderful character, one who is ahead of her time in her view of people who are different than her. She is a Jew who sees her Black neighbors not as lesser in any way, but as fascinating individuals worthy of the same treatment as anyone else. She’s a fighter, and I love her. I also loved DoDo, the deaf Black boy who becomes so central to the story. And I was captivated by Nate, who seems so steady but can be absolutely terrifying when called for. There’s Moshe, Chona’s theater owner husband; Malachi, the dancing Jew who waltzes in when Moshe needs a friend; Addy, Chona’s Black caretaker and wife to Nate, both of whom are DoDo’s adopted parents; Fatty, the Black with a seemingly endless amount of odd jobs; Doc Roberts, the white doctor in town who doesn’t see himself as racist, but who absolutely is, and who is the source of so much pain in the book. There are many more, as there was a huge and wildly varied cast that was difficult to keep straight, but these were the standouts for me.There were elements of this story that were absolutely heartbreaking. And yet, strangely, I could never feel as sad as those scenes should have merited. There's something about McBride's storytelling that feels tongue-in-cheek and humorous, even in spaces where levity clashes with the story being told. This kept the book from feeling too heavy, which I appreciated, but it was somewhat jarring. I remember this also being the case with Deacon King Kong when I read it, though I think that peculiar tone worked better there, in my opinion.I saw other ers compare this book to jazz music, and I think that’s accurate. Jazz music abhors structure, and The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store meandered and crescendoed and built in ways and places I didn’t expect and couldn’t predict. Jazz is something that I appreciate and respect, especially as a musician, but it’s not a genre that really resonates with me. It’ll never be the type of music I’m drawn to. And that’s how I felt about this book. I respect and appreciate it, but the style and structure didn’t really speak to me....more

title: Key of Valor        (Key Trilogy, #3)
author: Roberts, Nora*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If Nora Roberts is my ultimate comfort author (which she is), then this trilogy is my ultimate comfort trilogy. Of the dozens of trilogies and quartetIf Nora Roberts is my ultimate comfort author (which she is), then this trilogy is my ultimate comfort trilogy. Of the dozens of trilogies and quartets I’ve read from her, the Key trilogy is my favorite. There are others that I love, that I also return to again and again for comfort. And then there are those that I really respect, such as the Chronicle of the One. But this trilogy I respect and admire and love deeply. It just really resonates with me. And I can’t believe I’ve never ed it!Our story begins with three very different women from the same small town being invited to a mysterious mansion on a dark and stormy night. There they are given a quest of mythic proportions: find three keys to free the souls of three demigoddesses over the course of three months, and each woman will win a million dollars. But, of course, there are stakes. Should they accept the quest but fail to deliver, they will each lose an undisclosed year of their lives. The women, Mallory, Dana, and Zoe, must believe in the seemingly impossible and band together in order to complete their task and win the prize. This third installment is Zoe’s story. She has the most pressure on her, as both of her friends have already succeeded in finding their keys. She’s also the only member of the triad with someone who has to come before her search or herself: her 9 year-old son, Simon. Zoe got pregnant at sixteen, but she refused to raise her child in the same run-down trailer park where she grew up. She left and, through a lot of hard work, made a great life for herself and Simon. She pinched and scraped as a hair stylist to buy a diamond-in-the-rough of a house and turn it into a lovely, charming, cozy home. And now she’s opening her own place, after years of dreaming and planning. In spite of the stressful search for the key, her life is going better than she could have hoped. Now, if she could just figure out what to do about Bradley.Bradley Vane, completing the triad of male friends who have served as romantic leads, is the heir to the HomeMakers chain, which is a bit like Lowe’s or Home Depot. He is swimming in money, and that is all Zoe sees at first. Which is unfortunate, because she wants absolutely nothing to do with rich guys; been there, done that. So, poor Bradley starts off on the wrong foot with a woman whose face he fell in love with years ago, when he saw her likeness in a painting. Luckily, Bradley is a hard worker, and he’s up to the task of winning her over. It helps that he’s completely in love with Simon, bonding with the boy over video games. Zoe is so courageous. She is the fiercest of the three, so it’s fitting that she must find the Key of Valor. She’s a gorgeous, creative, hardworking mama bear, and I have so much respect for her as a character. I adore her relationship with her son. Simon is brimming with personality, and I was delighted with him every time he took centerstage. Their little family was just a joy to visit.I also love the friendship that buds between Mallory, Dana, and Zoe. I also absolutely adore the business venture they embark upon together in the form of Indulgence, a combination art gallery, bookstore, and salon. It just sounds incredible, and is the fictional shop I have daydreamed about the most in my life. One of Nora’s strengths as a writer is her easy way with poetic descriptions of places, and that is on brilliant display in this trilogy, not only in Indulgence, but in the houses of our various characters as well as Warrior’s Peak, the aforementioned mysterious mansion. Nora paints beautiful pictures with her words here.While I’m sure there are plenty of legitimate critiques that could be made of this book and the rest of the trilogy, I have no notes for this story. It’s an incredibly subjective 5 stars. I just love the Key trilogy so much. It’s something I can sink back into anytime I need something cozy, and it’s a story that I think about frequently. If you’ve ever thought about reading a Nora Roberts trilogy but didn’t know which one to try first, start here!...more

title: The City of Stardust
author: Summers, Georgia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I received an advance copy of this novel from the publisher, Orbit/Redhook, in exchange for an honest .The description for The City of Stardust I received an advance copy of this novel from the publisher, Orbit/Redhook, in exchange for an honest .The description for The City of Stardust captivated me as soon as I read it. Here’s what hooked me: “A young woman descends into a seductive magical underworld of power-hungry scholars, fickle gods and monsters bent on revenge to break her family's curse in this spellbinding contemporary fantasy debut.” There are so many things that grab me in that little synopsis. A “seductive, magical underworld?” Sign me up. “Power-hungry scholars?” Forever and always. Fickle gods and family curses? Yes, please. While I did get all of those things, the story itself didn’t land quite as solidly for me as I had hoped it would. This story brought to mind a multitude of others. I was reminded of The Ten Thousand Doors of January in bits and pieces of the writing style, as well as in the key and door motifs. Strange the Dreamer came to mind in terms of tone and texture, and even the story itself. There was a whiff of The Starless Sea, a subtle hint of The Night Circus. By and large, these are books that I adore. So to say that my expectations for The City of Stardust were through the roof would be an understatement. And high expectations are always risky.I found this to be one of those odd stories that is strongest in the middle. It got off to a bit of a slow start, and the finish felt shaky and not wholly formed. But the middle 200 pages or so were incredibly engaging. This was the quest portion of the tale, and it was well crafted and well delivered. It was here that I found our main characters, Violet and Aleksander, to be at their most compelling. The various settings were all beautifully rendered. I felt that the pacing and tension, both in terms of plot and romantic undertones, were wonderfully balanced in this section. I could have overlooked the weaker beginning had the ending not unraveled. At least, it did so in my eyes. The tension dissipated where it should have been the tightest.I liked The City of Stardust, and there were aspects of it that I absolutely love. The descriptions of Violet’s bookish childhood was fantastic. I loved Ambrose and Gabriel, Violet’s uncles, though I actually wish they had been given more time on the page. I was fascinated by the hidden world of Fidelis, and the scholarly underworld that had found its way from that world into our own. Aleksander was a very intriguing character, and I was never quite sure where he was going to fall in terms of relationship with Violet. The mythos here was pretty fascinating, and the supernatural entities were a wonderful blend of awe-inspiring and terrifying. Georgia Summers created something lovely in The City of Stardust, if a touch unbalanced in terms of pacing and a maintenance of tension. I might have felt a bit ambivalent about the way things wrapped up, but by and large I think this was a solid debut. If everything that comes from Summers’ pen is this lovely, I can’t wait to read whatever she puts out next!...more
